body: ### Problem when i use vim.pack.updata() ### Steps to reproduce nvim --clean :lua vim.pack.update() ### Expected behavior doc saied that this cmd will update all packs ### Nvim version (nvim -v) NVIM v0.12.0-dev-1471+gbe73c35943 ### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same? no, vim doesn't have vim.pack ### Operating system/version windows & macOS ### Terminal name/version windows terminal ### $TERM environment variable xterm-256color ### Installation build from source

comment_data.body: Hmm I can't reproduce this with `v0.12.0-dev-1471+gbe73c35943`. Could you also please share your `nvim-pack-lock.json` file?

I just ran into this issue. The problem is that you have deleted a plugin from the list of strings installing plugins in `add()` but have not first run `del()` on the plugin, or deleted the plugin on disk. The plugin still exists in `site/pack/core/opt/`.

I think this is a Neovim issue where it's trying to update a plugin it partially recognises, but which has never had `add()` called on it (in the current Neovim session, at least) because Neovim is reading outdated plugin data from somewhere. This issue may have started appearing in about the last week, since I think I had some plugins hanging around that I had removed from the `add()` call but had not explicitly deleted yet. I first noticed this problem a couple of days ago.

To fix your immediate problem, delete the offending plugin(s) from `~/.local/share/nvim/site/pack/core/opt/`.

After a brief read this looks related, perhaps there's an unwanted interaction involving the pack lock file too:
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/36231

> The problem is that you have deleted a plugin from the list of strings installing plugins in `add()` but have not first run `del()` on the plugin, or deleted the plugin on disk.

Confirmed. At minimum we can at least show a more useful error, but probably worth the cost to actually handle this case somehow.

> I just ran into this issue. The problem is that you have deleted a plugin from the list of strings installing plugins in `add()` but have not first run `del()` on the plugin, or deleted the plugin on disk. The plugin still exists in `site/pack/core/opt/`.

These steps alone do not lead to the error. There has to be some manual not (yet) supported action involving files that `vim.pack` expects to be managed exclusively by it.

Lockfile from [this comment](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/36254#issuecomment-3420618730) contains entries like `"dashboard-nvim": [],` which do not occur if everything is done according to the documentation. This looks similar to actions described in #36162.

> Confirmed. At minimum we can at least show a more useful error, but probably worth the cost to actually handle this case somehow.

There is a plan to make a PR that addresses #36162 and other robustness issues by the end of the week. My main concern was the performance cost for the "happy path" of regular startup loading, but after some preliminary profiling I think it should be okay.

Edit: sorry, just read https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/36162, looks like you're already aware of the below issue ðŸ˜ 

**(TLDR: delete the lockfile and it repopulates with (almost) only `[]` data for all plugins)**

The majority of the plugins in my lockfile have empty `[]` data. (Just speculating but) it might have arisen for me because I build Neovim from the latest commit on git, pulling once or twice a week, and the lockfile has data in it from when pack behaved differently? I don't think I'm doing anything unusual (one `add({})` call with all the URLs) and before this issue I've never added / deleted data in the `site/pack/core/opt/` directory.

Right now, when plugins are updated, their `[]` data changes to `{ "rev": "abcd123" }` (and for one, `{ "rev": "abcd123", "src": "https://github.com/..."  }` ) which is perhaps more what you'd expect.

However when I delete the lockfile entirely, it is recreated but only contains data from the `add()` call e.g. `{ "version": "1.0.0 - 2.0.0" }` or `{ "version": "'main'" }` while all plugins without any extra config revert to only `[]` data.

title: vim.pack.update() -> expected non-empty string, got nil
